dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: That is a huge number, but it's actually a drop from where they were, right? The report says assets plummeted to that level.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That is a huge number, but it's actually a drop from where they were, right? The report says assets plummeted to that level.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The report, titled The rising attractiveness of alternative asset classes for Sovereign Wealth Funds, finds that, despite SWFs facing adverse conditions since 2014 when asset growth began to stall as a result of falling oil prices, total assets under management still grew to US$7.4 trillion in 2016, albeit at a slower pace than prior years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it hasn't recovered since. Even with oil prices rising after 2014, which you'd think would help these funds grow.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it hasn't recovered since. Even with oil prices rising after twenty fourteen, which you'd think would help these funds grow.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The report, titled The rising attractiveness of alternative asset classes for Sovereign Wealth Funds, finds that, despite SWFs facing adverse conditions since 2014 when asset growth began to stall as a result of falling oil prices, total assets under management still grew to US$7.4 trillion in 2016, albeit at a slower pace than prior years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And now they're narrowing their strategies, moving into things like government bonds, which KPMG thinks will cause growth to stagnate.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And now they're narrowing their strategies, moving into things like government bonds, which K P M G thinks will cause growth to stagnate.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The pressure felt since 2014 is driving SWFs to broaden their investment strategies and PwC expects the growth rate of assets under management to increase in the coming years as SWFs invest in non-fossil sources and diversify their portfolios to include alternative investments to enhance returns. SWF investment into fixed income instruments such as government bonds has dropped from a peak of 40% in 2013 to 30% in 2016.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm, they're really shifting away from non-fossil sources too. Corporate bond investments went from 20% to 30% between 2016 and 2018.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm, they're really shifting away from non-fossil sources too. Corporate bond investments went from twenty percent to thirty percent between twenty sixteen and twenty eighteen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The pressure felt since 2014 is driving SWFs to broaden their investment strategies and PwC expects the growth rate of assets under management to increase in the coming years as SWFs invest in non-fossil sources and diversify their portfolios to include alternative investments to enhance returns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is interesting because interest rate cuts are expected in Europe and the U.S., but the report says they'll be substantial—so not much incentive to chase yield in traditional areas.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is interesting because interest rate cuts are expected in Europe and the U.S., but the report says they'll be substantial-so not much incentive to chase yield in traditional areas.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The report acknowledges expected interest rate hikes across Europe and the United States but predicts they will be moderate, encouraging SWFs to continue searching for yield by allocating investment to non-traditional areas.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right. But then there's this point about alternative assets—most are highly liquid, except for, like, Bitcoin, which has really low daily trading volume.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. But then there's this point about alternative assets-most are highly liquid, except for, like, Bitcoin, which has really low daily trading volume.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The report notes that including certain alternative asset classes is not without risks as the majority of alternatives are highly illiquid. An exception is gold, which has one of the highest rates of daily volumes exchanged and can provide protection against short and medium term market corrections.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, Bitcoin's mentioned as a weakness during market expansions. Will Jackson-Moore from Deloitte also weighed in on this, didn't he?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, Bitcoin's mentioned as a weakness during market expansions. Will Jackson-Moore from Deloitte also weighed in on this, didn't he?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Will Jackson-Moore, PwCs global head of sovereign investment funds and private equity, commented: Post-Davos Depression Ive been attending the World Economic Forums annual conference in Davos, ...

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: He did—he said Public Pension Funds help governments destabilize the economy and exchange rates? That wording seems a bit odd, but anyway...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He did-he said Public Pension Funds help governments destabilize the economy and exchange rates? That wording seems a bit odd, but anyway...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Sovereign Wealth Funds play an important role helping governments stabilise the economy and exchange rates.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, uh, maybe it's a misquote? But he expects traditional investments to stay prominent despite decreased diversification and erosion of principal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, uh, maybe it's a misquote? But he expects traditional investments to stay prominent despite decreased diversification and erosion of principal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We expect alternatives to be prominent in SWF portfolios in the future as they can offer increased diversification, principal protection, a hedge against inflation, and an increase in portfolio performance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And he mentions that excluding alternatives can bring benefits like liquidity and simplicity. But then he says the costs might outweigh the benefits?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And he mentions that excluding alternatives can bring benefits like liquidity and simplicity. But then he says the costs might outweigh the benefits?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That being said, finding the right allocation strategy for these asset classes is crucial as including certain alternatives might introduce a new set of risks such as illiquidity, complexity, and cyclicality. Overall though, the benefits seem to outweigh the costs, as the varied nature of alternatives provides SWFs with the ability to select an asset class specific to their investment needs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's a bit contradictory, but I think the key is finding the right allocation. They stress reallocating based on market trends.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a bit contradictory, but I think the key is finding the right allocation. They stress reallocating based on market trends.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: SWFs should keep in mind the need for continuous monitoring of their portfolios and their investments and reallocate their capital to reflect economic developments. Overall though, the benefits seem to outweigh the costs, as the varied nature of alternatives provides SWFs with the ability to select an asset class specific to their investment needs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: True. Still, the overall picture is that these funds are under pressure and simplifying their portfolios might not be the magic solution everyone hopes for.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True. Still, the overall picture is that these funds are under pressure and simplifying their portfolios might not be the magic solution everyone hopes for.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The pressure felt since 2014 is driving SWFs to broaden their investment strategies and PwC expects the growth rate of assets under management to increase in the coming years as SWFs invest in non-fossil sources and diversify their portfolios to include alternative investments to enhance returns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. It's a tricky balance between safety and growth, especially with so much capital at stake.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. It's a tricky balance between safety and growth, especially with so much capital at stake.

artist_script:
US$3.4 trillion in assets under management for Public Pension Funds as of 2018.
HostA: That is a huge number, but it's actually a drop from where they were, right? The report says assets plummeted to that level.
HostB: Yeah, and it hasn't recovered since. Even with oil prices rising after 2014, which you'd think would help these funds grow.
HostA: Exactly. And now they're narrowing their strategies, moving into things like government bonds, which KPMG thinks will cause growth to stagnate.
HostB: Mhm, they're really shifting away from non-fossil sources too. Corporate bond investments went from 20% to 30% between 2016 and 2018.
HostA: Which is interesting because interest rate cuts are expected in Europe and the U.S., but the report says they'll be substantial—so not much incentive to chase yield in traditional areas.
HostB: Right. But then there's this point about alternative assets—most are highly liquid, except for, like, Bitcoin, which has really low daily trading volume.
HostA: Oh yeah, Bitcoin’s mentioned as a weakness during market expansions. Will Jackson-Moore from Deloitte also weighed in on this, didn't he?
HostB: He did—he said Public Pension Funds help governments destabilize the economy and exchange rates? That wording seems a bit odd, but anyway...
HostA: Yeah, uh, maybe it's a misquote? But he expects traditional investments to stay prominent despite decreased diversification and erosion of principal.
HostB: And he mentions that excluding alternatives can bring benefits like liquidity and simplicity. But then he says the costs might outweigh the benefits?
HostA: It's a bit contradictory, but I think the key is finding the right allocation. They stress reallocating based on market trends.
HostB: True. Still, the overall picture is that these funds are under pressure and simplifying their portfolios might not be the magic solution everyone hopes for.
HostA: For sure. It's a tricky balance between safety and growth, especially with so much capital at stake.
